discussion.p:
Following document number about signal-safe instructions Signal handlers, and it's unclear whether std::atomic_flag is signal-safe.
Formally it doesn't fit any of the mentioned conditions:

li.p: f is a non-static member function invoked on an object A, such that A.is_lock_free() yields true, or

blockquote.p: (there is no is_lock_free method in std::atomic_flag class)

li.p: f is a non-member function, and for every pointer-to-atomic argument A passed to f, atomic_is_lock_free(A) yields true

blockquote.p: (std::atomic_flag object can't be passed to atomic_is_lock_free as argument)

discussion.p:
However, std::atomic_flag seem to fit well here, it's atomic, and it's always lock-free.
The suggestion is as follows: If std::atomic_flag is signal-safe, then it should be explicitly mentioned in , e.g., the following lines should be added:

p.ins: f is a non-static member function invoked on an atomic_flag object, or
f is a non-member function, and every pointer-to-atomic argument passed to f is atomic_flag, or

discussion.p: If the std::atomic_flag is not signal-safe, the following note could be added:

p.ins: [Note: Even though atomic_flag is atomic and lock-free, it's not signal-safe. — end note]

discussion.p: Set priority to 3 after reflector poll. Send to SG1.
Another way to fix this is to add is_always_lock_free (=true) and is_lock_free() { return true; } to atomic_flag.

Poll: Adopt the proposed resolution for LWG3756
"f is a non-static member function invoked on an atomic_flag object, or"
"f is a non-member function, and every pointer-to- atomic argument passed to f is atomic_flag, or"

blockquote.p: -1- A call to the function signal synchronizes with any resulting invocation of the signal handler so installed.
-2- A plain lock-free atomic operation is an invocation of a function f from , such that:

ol.li: (2.1) — f is the function atomic_is_lock_free(), or
(2.2) — f is the member function is_lock_free(), or

li.ins: (2.?) — f is a non-static member function invoked on an atomic_flag object, or
(2.?) — f is a non-member function, and every pointer-to-atomic argument passed to f is atomic_flag, or

ol.li: (2.3) — f is a non-static member function invoked on an object A, such that A.is_lock_free() yields true, or
(2.4) — f is a non-member function, and for every pointer-to-atomic argument A passed to f, atomic_is_lock_free(A) yields true.

blockquote.p: -3- An evaluation is signal-safe unless it includes one of the following:

ol.li:
(3.1) — a call to any standard library function, except for plain lock-free atomic operations and functions explicitly identified as signal-safe;
[Note 1: This implicitly excludes the use of new and delete expressions that rely on a library-provided memory allocator. — end note]
(3.2) — an access to an object with thread storage duration;
(3.3) — a dynamic_cast expression;
(3.4) — throwing of an exception;
(3.5) — control entering a try-block or function-try-block;
(3.6) — initialization of a variable with static storage duration requiring dynamic initialization (, )206; or
(3.7) — waiting for the completion of the initialization of a variable with static storage duration ().

blockquote.p: A signal handler invocation has undefined behavior if it includes an evaluation that is not signal-safe.
-1- A call to the function signal synchronizes with any resulting invocation of the signal handler so installed.
-2- A plain lock-free atomic operation is an invocation of a function f from , such that:

ol.li: (2.1) — f is the function atomic_is_lock_free(), or
(2.2) — f is the member function is_lock_free(), or

li.ins: (2.?) — f is a non-static member function of class atomic_flag, or
(2.?) — f is a non-member function, and the first parameter of f has type cv atomic_flag*, or

ol.li: (2.3) — f is a non-static member function invoked on an object A, such that A.is_lock_free() yields true, or
(2.4) — f is a non-member function, and for every pointer-to-atomic argument A passed to f, atomic_is_lock_free(A) yields true.
